trans-unit.source: Provides top-level navigation while conserving screen real estate.
trans-unit.target: Provides top-level navigation while conserving screen real estate.

trans-unit.source: Guidelines for navigation panes
trans-unit.target: Guidelines for navigation panes

trans-unit.source: Nav panes
trans-unit.target: Nav panes

trans-unit.source: A navigation pane (or just "nav" pane) is a pattern that allows for many top-level navigation items while conserving screen real estate.
trans-unit.target: A navigation pane (or just "nav" pane) is a pattern that allows for many top-level navigation items while conserving screen real estate.

trans-unit.source: The nav pane is widely used for mobile apps, but also works well on larger screens.
trans-unit.target: The nav pane is widely used for mobile apps, but also works well on larger screens.

trans-unit.source: When used as an overlay, the pane remains collapsed and out-of-the way until the user presses the button, which is handy for smaller screens.
trans-unit.target: When used as an overlay, the pane remains collapsed and out-of-the way until the user presses the button, which is handy for smaller screens.

trans-unit.source: When used in its docked mode, the pane remains open, which allows greater utility if there's enough screen real estate.
trans-unit.target: When used in its docked mode, the pane remains open, which allows greater utility if there's enough screen real estate.

trans-unit.source: Example of a nav pane
trans-unit.target: Example of a nav pane

trans-unit.source: Important APIs
trans-unit.target: Important APIs

trans-unit.source: SplitView class (XAML)
trans-unit.target: SplitView class (XAML)

trans-unit.source: SplitView object (HTML)
trans-unit.target: SplitView object (HTML)

trans-unit.source: Is this the right pattern?
trans-unit.target: Is this the right pattern?

trans-unit.source: The nav pane works well for:
trans-unit.target: The nav pane works well for:

trans-unit.source: Apps with many top-level navigation items that are in the same class, such as a sports app with categories like Football, Baseball, Basketball, Soccer, and so on.
trans-unit.target: Apps with many top-level navigation items that are in the same class, such as a sports app with categories like Football, Baseball, Basketball, Soccer, and so on.

trans-unit.source: Providing a consistent navigational experience across apps, provided that only navigational elements are placed within the pane.
trans-unit.target: Providing a consistent navigational experience across apps, provided that only navigational elements are placed within the pane.

trans-unit.source: A medium-to-high number (5-10+) of top-level navigational categories.
trans-unit.target: A medium-to-high number (5-10+) of top-level navigational categories.

trans-unit.source: Preserving screen real estate (as an overlay).
trans-unit.target: Preserving screen real estate (as an overlay).

trans-unit.source: Navigation items that are infrequently accessed.
trans-unit.target: Navigation items that are infrequently accessed.

trans-unit.source: (as an overlay).
trans-unit.target: (as an overlay).

trans-unit.source: Drag-and-drop scenarios (when docked).
trans-unit.target: Drag-and-drop scenarios (when docked).

trans-unit.source: Building a nav pane
trans-unit.target: Building a nav pane

trans-unit.source: The nav pane pattern consists of a button, a pane for navigation categories, and a content area.
trans-unit.target: The nav pane pattern consists of a button, a pane for navigation categories, and a content area.

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to build a nav pane is with a [split view control](split-view.md), which comes with an empty pane and a content area that's always visible.
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to build a nav pane is with a [split view control](split-view.md), which comes with an empty pane and a content area that's always visible.

trans-unit.source: The pane can either be visible or hidden, and can present itself from either the left side or right side of an app window.
trans-unit.target: The pane can either be visible or hidden, and can present itself from either the left side or right side of an app window.

trans-unit.source: If you'd like to build a nav pane without the split view control, you'll need three primary components: a button, a pane, and a content area.
trans-unit.target: If you'd like to build a nav pane without the split view control, you'll need three primary components: a button, a pane, and a content area.

trans-unit.source: The button allows the user to open and close the pane.
trans-unit.target: The button allows the user to open and close the pane.

trans-unit.source: The pane is a container for navigation elements.
trans-unit.target: The pane is a container for navigation elements.

trans-unit.source: The content area displays information from the selected navigation item.
trans-unit.target: The content area displays information from the selected navigation item.

trans-unit.source: The nav pane can also exist in a docked mode, in which the pane is always shown, so a button wouldn't be necessary in that case.
trans-unit.target: The nav pane can also exist in a docked mode, in which the pane is always shown, so a button wouldn't be necessary in that case.

trans-unit.source: Button
trans-unit.target: Button

trans-unit.source: The nav pane button is visualized, by default, as three stacked horizontal lines and is commonly referred to as the "hamburger" button.
trans-unit.target: The nav pane button is visualized, by default, as three stacked horizontal lines and is commonly referred to as the "hamburger" button.

trans-unit.source: The button allows the user to open and close the pane when needed and does not move with the pane.
trans-unit.target: The button allows the user to open and close the pane when needed and does not move with the pane.

trans-unit.source: We recommend placing the button in the upper-left corner of your app.
trans-unit.target: We recommend placing the button in the upper-left corner of your app.

trans-unit.source: The button does not move with the pane.
trans-unit.target: The button does not move with the pane.

trans-unit.source: Example of the nav pane button
trans-unit.target: Example of the nav pane button

trans-unit.source: The button is usually associated with a text string.
trans-unit.target: The button is usually associated with a text string.

trans-unit.source: At the top level of the app, the app title can be displayed next to the button.
trans-unit.target: At the top level of the app, the app title can be displayed next to the button.

trans-unit.source: At lower levels of the app, the text string can be associated with the page that the user is currently on.
trans-unit.target: At lower levels of the app, the text string can be associated with the page that the user is currently on.

trans-unit.source: Pane
trans-unit.target: Pane

trans-unit.source: Headers for navigational categories go in the pane.
trans-unit.target: Headers for navigational categories go in the pane.

trans-unit.source: Entry points to app settings and account management, if applicable, also go in the pane.
trans-unit.target: Entry points to app settings and account management, if applicable, also go in the pane.

trans-unit.source: Navigation headers can either be top-level, or nested top-level/second-level.
trans-unit.target: Navigation headers can either be top-level, or nested top-level/second-level.

trans-unit.source: Example of the nav pane's pane
trans-unit.target: Example of the nav pane's pane

trans-unit.source: Content area
trans-unit.target: Content area

trans-unit.source: The content area is where information for the selected nav location is displayed.
trans-unit.target: The content area is where information for the selected nav location is displayed.

trans-unit.source: It can contain individual elements or other sub-level navigation.
trans-unit.target: It can contain individual elements or other sub-level navigation.

trans-unit.source: Nav pane variations
trans-unit.target: Nav pane variations

trans-unit.source: The nav pane has two main variations, overlay and docked.
trans-unit.target: The nav pane has two main variations, overlay and docked.

trans-unit.source: An overlay collapses and expands as needed.
trans-unit.target: An overlay collapses and expands as needed.

trans-unit.source: A docked pane remains open by default.
trans-unit.target: A docked pane remains open by default.

trans-unit.source: Overlay
trans-unit.target: Overlay

trans-unit.source: An overlay can be used on any screen size and in either portrait or landscape orientation.
trans-unit.target: An overlay can be used on any screen size and in either portrait or landscape orientation.

trans-unit.source: In its default (collapsed) state, the overlay takes up no real-estate, with only the button shown.
trans-unit.target: In its default (collapsed) state, the overlay takes up no real-estate, with only the button shown.

trans-unit.source: Provides on-demand navigation that conserves screen real estate.
trans-unit.target: Provides on-demand navigation that conserves screen real estate.

trans-unit.source: Ideal for apps on phones and phablets.
trans-unit.target: Ideal for apps on phones and phablets.

trans-unit.source: The pane is hidden by default, with only the button visible.
trans-unit.target: The pane is hidden by default, with only the button visible.

trans-unit.source: Pressing the nav pane button opens and closes the overlay.
trans-unit.target: Pressing the nav pane button opens and closes the overlay.

trans-unit.source: The expanded state is transient and is dismissed when a selection is made, when the back button is used, or when the user taps outside of the pane.
trans-unit.target: The expanded state is transient and is dismissed when a selection is made, when the back button is used, or when the user taps outside of the pane.

trans-unit.source: The overlay draws over the top of content and does not reflow content.
trans-unit.target: The overlay draws over the top of content and does not reflow content.

trans-unit.source: Docked
trans-unit.target: Docked

trans-unit.source: The navigation pane remains open.
trans-unit.target: The navigation pane remains open.

trans-unit.source: This mode is better suited for larger screens, generally tablets and above.
trans-unit.target: This mode is better suited for larger screens, generally tablets and above.

trans-unit.source: In landscape orientation, the minimum screen width that can take advantage of the docked state is 720 epx.
trans-unit.target: In landscape orientation, the minimum screen width that can take advantage of the docked state is 720 epx.

trans-unit.source: The docked state at this size may require special attention to content scaling.
trans-unit.target: The docked state at this size may require special attention to content scaling.

trans-unit.source: Supports drag-and-drop scenarios to and from the pane.
trans-unit.target: Supports drag-and-drop scenarios to and from the pane.

trans-unit.source: The nav pane button is not required for this state.
trans-unit.target: The nav pane button is not required for this state.

trans-unit.source: If the button is used, then the content area is pushed out and the content within that area will reflow.
trans-unit.target: If the button is used, then the content area is pushed out and the content within that area will reflow.

trans-unit.source: The selection should be shown on the list items to highlight where the user is in the navigation tree.
trans-unit.target: The selection should be shown on the list items to highlight where the user is in the navigation tree.

trans-unit.source: When the device is too narrow in portrait orientation to display the docked pane, the following behavior is recommended when a device is rotated:
trans-unit.target: When the device is too narrow in portrait orientation to display the docked pane, the following behavior is recommended when a device is rotated:

trans-unit.source: Landscape-to-portrait.
trans-unit.target: Landscape-to-portrait.

trans-unit.source: The pane collapses to either the overlay state or minimized state.
trans-unit.target: The pane collapses to either the overlay state or minimized state.

trans-unit.source: Portrait-to-landscape.
trans-unit.target: Portrait-to-landscape.

trans-unit.source: The pane reappears.
trans-unit.target: The pane reappears.

trans-unit.source: Examples
trans-unit.target: Examples

trans-unit.source: In this design for a news app, we see the nav pane collapsed on the left and expanded on the right.
trans-unit.target: In this design for a news app, we see the nav pane collapsed on the left and expanded on the right.

trans-unit.source: In the expanded pane, each content category in the list view (World, Local, and so on) has its own sub-categories for more granular navigation.
trans-unit.target: In the expanded pane, each content category in the list view (World, Local, and so on) has its own sub-categories for more granular navigation.

trans-unit.source: Example of an app using nav pane
trans-unit.target: Example of an app using nav pane

trans-unit.source: Here's an example of the same news app design, but as it would appear on a laptop or desktop.
trans-unit.target: Here's an example of the same news app design, but as it would appear on a laptop or desktop.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the nav pane is collapsed and takes up no screen real estate.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the nav pane is collapsed and takes up no screen real estate.

trans-unit.source: Example of a collapsed nav pane in a news app on desktop
trans-unit.target: Example of a collapsed nav pane in a news app on desktop

trans-unit.source: In this example, the nav pane is expanded, and pushes content to the right.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the nav pane is expanded, and pushes content to the right.

trans-unit.source: In this view, a "Manage resources" button appears at the bottom of the pane.
trans-unit.target: In this view, a "Manage resources" button appears at the bottom of the pane.

trans-unit.source: This is where you could put a button that navigates to app settings or a similar page that's not not regularly accessed.
trans-unit.target: This is where you could put a button that navigates to app settings or a similar page that's not not regularly accessed.

trans-unit.source: Example of an expanded nav pane in a news app on desktop
trans-unit.target: Example of an expanded nav pane in a news app on desktop

trans-unit.target: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows 10.
